description: Master the fundamentals of motion, forces, energy, and momentum in this comprehensive mechanics course.

slides.title: Introduction to Mechanics
slides.content:
# What is Mechanics? üçé

Mechanics is the branch of physics that deals with the **motion of objects** and the **forces** that affect that motion. It is the foundation of classical physics.

## Key Areas
- **Kinematics**: Describes motion without considering its causes (e.g., "how fast?")
- **Dynamics**: Deals with the forces that cause motion (e.g., "why does it move?")
- **Statics**: Studies bodies at rest on in equilibrium.

> üí° **Fun Fact:** Sir Isaac Newton laid the groundwork for classical mechanics in his work *Principia Mathematica* in 1687.

slides.title: Kinematics: Position & Displacement
slides.content:
# Understanding Motion üìç

To describe motion, we first need to know where something is.

## Position ($x$)
The location of an object relative to a reference point (origin).

## Distance vs. Displacement
- **Distance ($d$)**: The total path length traveled. (Scalar quantity)
- **Displacement ($\Delta x$)**: The change in position. Vector (has direction).

$$\Delta x = x_f - x_i$$
where $x_f$ is final position and $x_i$ is initial position.

> üö∂ **Example:** If you walk 5m Forward and 2m Back:
> - Distance = 5 + 2 = 7m
> - Displacement = 5 - 2 = 3m Forward

slides.title: Speed and Velocity
slides.content:
# How Fast? üèéÔ∏è

## Speed
Rate of change of distance. A scalar quantity (magnitude only).
$$Speed = \frac{Distance}{Time}$$

## Velocity ($v$)
Rate of change of displacement. A vector quantity (magnitude & direction).
$$v = \frac{\Delta x}{\Delta t}$$

- **Average Velocity**: Total displacement divided by total time.
- **Instantaneous Velocity**: Velocity at a specific moment.

slides.title: Acceleration
slides.content:
# Changing Motion üöÄ

**Acceleration ($a$)** is the rate of change of velocity.

$$a = \frac{\Delta v}{\Delta t} = \frac{v_f - v_i}{t}$$

- If velocity is constant, acceleration is **zero**.
- Acceleration can happen by:
  1. Changing speed (speeding up/slowing down)
  2. Changing direction (turning)

> ‚ö†Ô∏è **Note:** "Deceleration" is just acceleration in the opposite direction of motion.

slides.title: Kinematics Check
slides.content: Test your knowledge of motion basics.
slides.quizQuestion: A car travels 100 km North, then 100 km South. What is its displacement?

slides.title: Equations of Motion
slides.content:
# The SUVAT Equations üìê

For constant acceleration, we use these key equations:

1. $$v = u + at$$
2. $$s = ut + \frac{1}{2}at^2$$
3. $$v^2 = u^2 + 2as$$
4. $$s = \frac{(u+v)}{2}t$$

**Variables:**
- $s$: Displacement
- $u$: Initial velocity
- $v$: Final velocity
- $a$: Acceleration
- $t$: Time

slides.title: Newton's First Law
slides.content:
# The Law of Inertia üõë

**Newton's First Law:**
An object remains at rest or in uniform motion unless acted upon by a net external force.

## Inertia
The tendency of an object to resist changes in its state of motion. 
- **Mass** is a measure of inertia.
- More mass = More inertia (harder to move or stop).

> üèí **Example:** An ice hockey puck glides almost forever because friction (an external force) is very low.

slides.title: Newton's Second Law
slides.content:
# Force and Acceleration ü§ú

**Newton's Second Law:**
The acceleration of an object is directly proportional to the net force acting on it and inversely proportional to its mass.

$$F_{net} = ma$$

- **Force ($F$)** is measured in Newtons ($N$).
- $1 N = 1 kg \cdot m/s^2$

This is the most critical equation in mechanics!

slides.title: Newton's Third Law
slides.content:
# Action and Reaction üëè

**Newton's Third Law:**
For every action, there is an equal and opposite reaction.

- Forces always come in **pairs**.
- Action and reaction forces act on **different objects**.

> üöÄ **Rocket Science:** A rocket exerts force down on gases; the gases exert an equal force up on the rocket (thrust).

slides.title: Friction
slides.content:
# The Opposing Force üåµ

**Friction** is a resistive force that opposes motion between surfaces in contact.

$$f = \mu N$$

- $\mu$ (mu): Coefficient of friction (depends on materials).
- $N$: Normal force (perpendicular contact force).

## Types
1. **Static Friction**: Prevents motion from starting.
2. **Kinetic Friction**: Acts opposes motion of sliding objects.
(Static friction is usually stronger than kinetic!)

slides.title: Newton's Laws Quiz
slides.content: Apply the laws of motion.
slides.quizQuestion: If you push a 10kg box with 50N of force on a frictionless surface, what is its acceleration?

slides.title: Work
slides.content:
# Defining Work üë∑

In physics, **Work ($W$)** is done when a force causes displacement.

$$W = F \cdot d \cdot \cos(\theta)$$

- $F$: Force applied
- $d$: Displacement
- $\theta$: Angle between force and displacement vectors

- Measured in **Joules ($J$)**.
- No displacement = No work done (even if you get tired!).

slides.title: Energy
slides.content:
# The Capacity to do Work üîã

**Energy** is the ability to do work. It exists in many forms.

## Kinetic Energy ($KE$)
Energy of motion.
$$KE = \frac{1}{2}mv^2$$

## Potential Energy ($PE$)
Stored energy due to position.
- **Gravitational PE**: $PE_g = mgh$
- **Elastic PE**: $PE_s = \frac{1}{2}kx^2$ (springs)

slides.title: Conservation of Energy
slides.content:
# Energy Never Dies ‚ôªÔ∏è

**Law of Conservation of Energy:**
Energy cannot be created or destroyed, only transformed from one form to another.

$$E_{total} = KE + PE = constant$$

(In the absence of non-conservative forces like friction, mechanical energy is conserved.)

slides.title: Power
slides.content:
# Rate of Work ‚ö°

**Power ($P$)** is how quickly work is done or energy is transferred.

$$P = \frac{Work}{Time} = \frac{\Delta E}{t}$$

- Measured in **Watts ($W$)**.
- 1 Watt = 1 Joule/second.
- Also, $P = F \cdot v$ (Force $\times$ Velocity).

slides.title: Momentum
slides.content:
# Mass in Motion üêò

**Linear Momentum ($p$)** is a vector quantity.

$$p = mv$$

- Harder to stop heavier or faster objects.
- **Impulse ($J$)**: Change in momentum.
$$J = \Delta p = F \Delta t$$
This explains why airbags save lives (increasing time $\Delta t$ reduces force $F$).

slides.title: Conservation of Momentum
slides.content:
# Collisions üé±

In a closed system (no external forces), total momentum is conserved.

$$p_{initial} = p_{final}$$
$$m_1u_1 + m_2u_2 = m_1v_1 + m_2v_2$$

## Types of Collisions
1. **Elastic**: Kinetic energy IS conserved (billiard balls).
2. **Inelastic**: Kinetic energy IS NOT conserved (cars crashing and sticking).

slides.title: Gravitation
slides.content:
# Universal Attraction ü™ê

**Newton's Law of Universal Gravitation:**
Every particle attracts every other particle.

$$F_g = G \frac{m_1 m_2}{r^2}$$

- $G$: Gravitational constant
- $r$: Distance between centers

Gravity is what keeps planets in orbit!

slides.title: Projectile Motion
slides.content:
# Curved Paths üèπ

Motion in 2D with constant horizontal velocity and constant vertical acceleration (gravity).

- **Horizontal ($x$)**: $a_x = 0$, $v_x$ is constant.
- **Vertical ($y$)**: $a_y = -g$ ($9.8 m/s^2$).

The path of a projectile is a **parabola**.

slides.title: Mechanics Summary
slides.content:
# You've Mastered Mechanics! üéì

## Key Takeaways
- **Motion** is described by displacement, velocity, and acceleration.
- **Newton's Laws** govern how forces affect motion.
- **Energy** is conserved, transforming between Kinetic and Potential.
- **Momentum** describes the impact of collisions.

Mechanics is the toolkit for understanding the physical universe around us. Great job!
